name: C Programming: Complete Course
description: A complete, in-depth C programming course starting from basics to systems-level programming topics: pointers, memory management, data structures and file I/O with practical exercises.
whatYouLearn: C program structure, compilation and debugging
Primitive types, operators and control flow
Pointers, arrays and dynamic memory management
Basic data structures (linked list, stack, queue) in C

exercises.title: Hello World Program
exercises.description: Write your first C program to print 'Hello, World!' and learn the compilation steps.
exercises.theory: C programs start at `main`. Use `#include` to include headers; compile with `gcc`.
exercises.objective: Write and compile a Hello World program using `gcc`.
hints: Use `-Wall` to show warnings: `gcc -Wall hello.c -o hello`

exercises.title: Functions & Parameters
exercises.description: Write functions with parameters and return values; practice pass-by-value.
exercises.theory: Functions break logic into reusable parts; arguments are passed by value in C.
exercises.objective: Create a function to compute GCD of two integers and call it from main.
exercises.initialCode: // declare gcd function and call it in main
requirements: Call from main and print result

exercises.title: Arrays and Strings
exercises.description: Work with arrays and C-style strings; implement string length and copy functions.
exercises.theory: Strings in C are char arrays terminated by '\0'. Be careful with buffer sizes and null terminators.
exercises.objective: Implement `my_strlen` and `my_strcpy` functions and test them.

exercises.title: Pointers & Dynamic Memory
exercises.description: Understand pointers, pointer arithmetic and dynamic allocation with `malloc`/`free`.
exercises.theory: Pointers store addresses. Use `malloc` to allocate heap memory and `free` to release it. Always check for NULL.
exercises.objective: Allocate an int array dynamically, fill it and free it.
hints: Use `sizeof *a` style to avoid type repetition

exercises.title: Structs, Enums & Typedefs
exercises.description: Define and use structures and enums; create functions that accept struct pointers.
exercises.theory: Structs group related data; pass by pointer to avoid copies. Enums provide named integer constants.
exercises.objective: Create a `Point` struct and function to compute distance (use `sqrt` from math.h).
requirements: Link with math (`-lm`) if needed on some systems

exercises.title: File I/O and Streams
exercises.description: Read and write files using `fopen`, `fgets`, `fprintf` and `fclose`.
exercises.theory: C standard I/O uses `FILE*`. Check return values for errors.
exercises.objective: Read a text file line-by-line and write lines with line numbers to another file.
exercises.initialCode: /* open input and output files and process lines */
hints: Use `feof`/`ferror` only when needed; prefer checking return of fgets

exercises.title: Linked List Implementation
exercises.description: Implement a singly linked list with insert, delete and traversal operations.
exercises.theory: Dynamic data structures often use malloc/free. Carefully manage pointers to avoid leaks and invalid accesses.
exercises.objective: Create a linked list storing integers and implement insert at head, delete value, and print list.
hints: Use double pointers (`Node **`) to simplify deletion logic

exercises.title: Makefile & Compilation Flags
exercises.description: Create a Makefile for a multi-file project and understand common gcc flags (`-Wall`, `-Werror`, `-O2`).
exercises.theory: Make automates builds. Use object files to avoid recompiling unchanged sources.
exercises.objective: Write a Makefile to build `app` from `main.c` and `utils.c`.
exercises.solutionCode:
CC=gcc
CFLAGS=-Wall -Wextra -O2
OBJ=main.o utils.o
app: $(OBJ)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -o $@ $(OBJ)
%.o: %.c
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c $<
clean:
	rm -f *.o app
requirements: Provide rules for object files and clean
hints: Use tabs (not spaces) before commands in Makefile

exercises.title: Final Project: Small CLI Utility in C
exercises.description: Create a small command line utility (e.g., text grep, CSV summarizer, or simple HTTP client using sockets) combining file I/O, argument parsing and modular code.
exercises.theory: Real-world C projects need error handling, modularity, makefiles and testing.
exercises.objective: Deliver a working CLI program with README and Makefile.
exercises.solutionCode: /* Example deliverables: main.c, parser.c/h, utils.c/h, Makefile and README describing usage */
requirements: Use modular files, Makefile, and proper error handling
hints: Start with small features and incrementally add functionality; test memory with valgrind if possible

references.title: The C Programming Language (K&R)
references.description: Classic book by Kernighan & Ritchie — essential reading for C.

references.title: GNU C Library Documentation
references.description: Reference for C standard library functions.
